title: 113_s2930
content: The Act is named the "Clay Hunt Suicide Prevention for American Veterans Act" or the "Clay Hunt SAV Act." It involves evaluating mental health care and suicide prevention programs of the Department of Veterans Affairs and Department of Defense. The Act, named the "Clay Hunt Suicide Prevention for American Veterans Act" or the "Clay Hunt SAV Act," mandates the evaluation of mental health care and suicide prevention programs by the Department of Veterans Affairs and Department of Defense. The evaluation includes using common metrics, assessing program effectiveness, and identifying the most and least effective programs. The evaluation of mental health care and suicide prevention programs by the Department of Veterans Affairs and Department of Defense must be conducted by an independent third party. Recommendations on program consolidation, resource allocation, and best practices for caring for individuals with mental health disorders or at risk of suicide are required. The evaluation of mental health care and suicide prevention programs must be conducted by an independent third party and submitted to the Secretary concerned. A report containing the evaluation must be submitted to the appropriate committees of Congress within one year. The term "appropriate committees of Congress" refers to specific Senate and House committees. The term "Secretary concerned" refers to the Secretary of Veterans Affairs for matters concerning the Department of Veterans Affairs, and the Secretary of Defense for matters concerning the Department of Defense. SEC. 3. Publication of internet website for mental health care services. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs is required to create a centralized internet website providing veterans with information on mental health care services. This website will include details on services available at different locations, such as social work offices, mental health clinics, staff information, and any other relevant details determined by the Secretary. The Secretary must update the information on the internet website every 90 days and ensure outreach includes details about the website. SEC. 4. IMPROVEMENTS TO HEALTH CARE MATTERS. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs and the Secretary of Defense, in consultation with the Chief of the National Guard Bureau, shall establish strategic relationships between reserve components of the Armed Forces and the Department of Veterans Affairs to facilitate mental health referrals, timely behavioral health services, and communication for members with service-connected disabilities being discharged. The Comptroller General of the United States will submit a report assessing the transition of care for post-traumatic stress disorder or traumatic brain injury to congressional defense committees and the Committees on Veterans' Affairs of the Senate and House of Representatives by April 1, 2015. The report will cover programs, policies, and regulations related to this transition of care. The report will assess the transition of care for post-traumatic stress disorder or traumatic brain injury, focusing on pharmaceutical treatment plans and collaboration between the Secretary of Defense and the Secretary of Veterans Affairs. The report will evaluate the transition of care from the Secretary of Defense to the Secretary of Veterans Affairs, specifically focusing on off-formulary waiver process efficiency, benefits and challenges of combining formularies, and other relevant issues identified by the Comptroller General. A pilot program is established for the repayment of educational loans for certain psychiatrists of the Veterans Health Administration. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs will implement a pilot program to repay loans for individuals who used them for psychiatric medicine education. Loans can be from governmental entities, private financial institutions, institutions of higher education, or other specified entities. Eligible individuals must meet certain criteria. Eligible individuals for the pilot program must be licensed or in a residency program for psychiatric medicine in the Veterans Health Administration. They must also show a commitment to a long-term career as a psychiatrist in the VA. The Secretary will select at least 10 individuals each year for the pilot program in psychiatric medicine within the Veterans Health Administration. Participants must agree to serve a period of obligated service in exchange for loan repayment. Loan repayments under the pilot program may cover educational expenses up to $120,000 per year of service. Participants must agree to serve in exchange for loan repayment. An individual who fails to fulfill the obligated service in the pilot program is liable to repay the amount received, reduced by the proportion of days served. The repayment must be made to the United States within one year of the breach. The Secretary must submit a report to the Committees on Veterans' Affairs of the Senate and House of Representatives within two years of the pilot program's start. The report should include the number of participants in the program and where they were employed by the Department, specifying rural or urban locations. The Secretary must submit an interim report to the Committees on Veterans' Affairs within 90 days after the pilot program ends, and a final report within one year. The reports should include an assessment of the quality of work by participants, the number of needed psychiatrists, and updates on the program. The Secretary will submit a report to the Committees on Veterans' Affairs regarding the number of pilot program participants still employed by the Department. Regulations will be prescribed for the program, including standards for loans and repayments. The pilot program will terminate three years after it begins. The Secretary of Defense must review staffing requirements for State Directors of Psychological Health in National Guard Commands and submit a report to Congress within 540 days of the Act's enactment. The report will be coordinated with the Chief of the National Guard Bureau and presented to the Committees on Armed Services and Veterans' Affairs of both the Senate and the House of Representatives. SEC. 7. Collaboration on suicide prevention efforts between the Department of Veterans Affairs and non-profit mental health organizations. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs can collaborate with non-profit mental health organizations to prevent veteran suicide by improving efficiency, exchanging resources, and jointly carrying out suicide prevention efforts. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs will appoint a Director of Suicide Prevention Coordination within the Department to collaborate with non-profit mental health organizations for suicide prevention efforts.
